    Chemical Tools for Illumination of Tuberculosis Biology, Virulence Mechanisms, and Diagnosis

    • Gautam Kumar
      Gautam Kumar
      Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai 400 076, Maharashtra, India
      More by Gautam Kumar
      View Biography
      • , 
    • Rishikesh Narayan*
      Rishikesh Narayan
      School of Chemical and Materials Sciences, Indian Institute of Technology Goa, Ponda 403 401, Goa, India
      *Email: [email protected]
      More by Rishikesh Narayan
      View Biography
      • , and 
    • Shobhna Kapoor*
      Shobhna Kapoor
      Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai 400 076, Maharashtra, India
      Wadhwani Research Center for Bioengineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Mumbai 400 076, Maharashtra, India
      *Email: [email protected]
      More by Shobhna Kapoor
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0003-3684-4312
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 24, 15308–15332

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Tuberculosis (TB) remains one of the deadliest infectious diseases and begs the scientific community to up the ante for research and exploration of completely novel therapeutic avenues. Chemical biology-inspired design of tunable chemical tools has aided in clinical diagnosis, facilitated discovery of therapeutics, and begun to enable investigation of virulence mechanisms at the host–pathogen interface of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This Perspective highlights chemical tools specific to mycobacterial proteins and the cell lipid envelope that have furnished rapid and selective diagnostic strategies and provided unprecedented insights into the function of the mycobacterial proteome and lipidome. We discuss chemical tools that have enabled elucidating otherwise intractable biological processes by leveraging the unique lipid and metabolite repertoire of mycobacterial species. Some of these probes represent exciting starting points with the potential to illuminate poorly understood aspects of mycobacterial pathogenesis, particularly the host membrane–pathogen interactions.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Chemical biology is a field of contemporary sciences that uses chemical tools—essentially small organic molecules—to probe biological processes in vitro and in vivo, while furnishing actionable molecular targets for therapeutics and diagnostics.(1−4) Chemical tools afford selective modulation of a biomolecular target function or structure and offer distinct advantages, such as quick and reversible modes of action and conditional modulators dictated by their dosage, and importantly they enable studying genetically intractable organisms.(5,6) Chemical tools serve as starting points for new drugs and diagnostic strategies, in addition to fueling research, particularly in infectious diseases wherein they are enabling the discovery of virulence requirements during pathogenesis.(7,8) On the other hand, many chemical tools have been designed based on the structure and mechanism of approved drugs. This crossover of knowledge between discovery of drugs and development of chemical tools has emerged as an area of immense interest and possibilities in clinical diagnostics and pharmacology.
    The World Health Organization and Center for Disease Control and Prevention estimated an alarming 10 million global cases of tuberculosis (TB) and an estimated 1.4 million deaths in 2018 alone.(9) Consistently, Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of TB, has been at the forefront of considerable research toward its detection and inhibition of its pathogenic mechanisms.(10−12) The severity of this infectious disease is further reinforced by the rampant over- and misuse of prevalent antibiotic therapy that has led to the emergence of antibiotic resistance.(13) Thus, understanding this pathogen at the molecular level, with emphasis on its interaction with the host, to develop efficient diagnostic and treatment modules remains a so far unmet challenge. In this regard, the synthetic toolkit afforded by chemical biology provides unique approaches to investigate TB, by the use of probes with tunable functionality, and its impact on pathogenesis.(14−16)
    Key parts of such a toolkit are the “chemical probes” for understanding the biological functions of Mtb factors involved in bacterial physiology, virulence regulation, and host–pathogen interactions. Various research groups worldwide have contributed toward generation of chemical probes centered on mycobacterial metabolites, amino acids, and lipids (glycolipids) to probe fundamental pathways in Mtb and in the same breath provide rapid and selective imaging tools for TB diagnosis.(17−19) Chemical biology probes to explore Mtb and TB have been spurred by advances in synthetic chemistry approaches such as bio-orthogonal chemical reactions. Notably, click-chemistry, cyclo-addition reactions, and Staudinger and tetrazine ligations have furnished novel alternatives for labeling of specific Mtb biomolecules, to identify their interacting partners and query their molecular functions in vitro, in vivo, and in whole animals.(20−23)
    In this Perspective, we focus on the development and application of chemical probes to (i) improve our collective understanding of Mtb biological pathways, including interaction with the host, to inform the design of next-generation therapeutics and (ii) foster rapid clinical TB diagnosis. These probes are broadly classified in two categories: membrane-focused and protein-based. In each category, they have been further organized according to their design, function, target, and applications. The first category contains chemical probes, which are derived from natural or synthetic analogues of lipid metabolites biosynthesized by Mtb and are incorporated into the bacterial cell envelope. The breadth of chemical probes in this area has substantially supported the recent progress toward the elucidation of Mtb cell wall assembly (Figure 1A). The second category of probes are inspired by mycobacterial proteins and enzymes and are utilized for specific enzyme labeling as well as for the identification of novel therapeutic targets. Similar seminal reviews exist that deliberate exhaustively on activity-based protein profiling,(24,25) trehalose-based probes for bacterial imaging in vitro and in vivo,(26) and investigating mycobacterial cell envelope structure and functions.(24) However, this work, while discussing recent progress along similar lines, diverges by reviewing fairly recent progress in the field of infection biology focused on how some of these chemical probes based on Mtb lipids(27) can be employed for inventorying membrane-centric host–pathogen cross-talk.(28) This represents an emerging field with potential to furnish novel drug targets in mycobacterial infections.(29) Finally, we explore the advantages and limitations for specific probe design and synthesis and conclude with ways in which medicinal chemistry-inspired chemical probes can further our understanding of specific virulence mechanisms. This uniquely equips this review to provide a comprehensive read on the actionable chemical biology approaches in mycobacteria biology and host–pathogen interactions.

    Mycobacterial Cell Wall and Associated Proteins: Inspiration for Selective Labeling Tools and Potential Drug Targets

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As most of the chemical biology tools and drug targets in Mtb developed over the years are implicated in the cell wall synthesis or its adaptive maintenance, we dedicate a section to the current understanding of the mycobacterial cell envelope and the associated protein machinery. Mtb possesses remarkable defense mechanisms against most front-line antibiotic drugs and host inflammatory response, which is largely attributed to the complex cell membrane architecture with unique lipid molecules, common to Corynebacterium-Mycobacterium species(30,31) (Figure 1A). In addition, the Mtb cell membrane also impedes rapid detection of bacilli due to its low permeability. These concerns collectively highlight the importance of lipid-based chemical tools for selective labeling of Mtb membranes to afford clinical diagnosis, as well as to understand the multitude of roles played by mycobacterial lipid in forming this robust permeability barrier.(32)
    The cell envelope comprises the cytoplasmic plasma membrane, also known as the inner membrane (IM), overlaid with a cross-linked network of peptidoglycan (PG) coupled to the highly branched arabinogalactan (AG), forming the peptidoglycan–arabinogalactan (AG-PG) complex. The AG-PG backbone is covalently linked with characteristic long-chain mycolic fatty acids (FAs) (C60–C90) constituting the outer membrane (OM), also known as the mycomembrane (MM).(33) The IM consists of standard glycerophospholipids such as phosphatidylinositol, phosphatidylethanolamine, cardiolipid, and phosphatidyl-dimannosides such as AC2PIMs.(31,34) PG that provides rigidity to the cell envelope consists of a glycan backbone and short cross-linked peptide side chains: d-alanine is one of the central molecules in the cross-linking step of PG assembly. N-Acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc or NAG) and N-acetylmuramic acid (MurNAc or NAM) linked via β(1→4) linkages, constituting the glycan strand, form the PG backbone. Each glycan strand of repeating units of the disaccharide NAG-NAM is further cross-linked by peptide chains.(35) In Mtb PGs, the MurNAc is oxidized to N-glycolylmuramic acid (MurNGlyc), a notable structural modification, which has a prominent role in pathogenesis.(36,37) The muramyl components of the backbone are attached to tetrapeptide side chains that cross-link to form a network-like construction. The tetrapeptide side chains in Mtb include l-alanyl-d-isoglutaminyl-meso-diaminopimelyl-d-alanine cross-linked between meso-diaminopimelic acid (m-DAP) and d-alanine (3→4).(38) Along with predominant 3→4 transpeptide linkages, the 3→3 m-DAP linkages are also prevalent.(39) When Mtb enters dormancy or a stationary phase, the adaptive response guides remodeling of the PG network by substitution of 3→4 cross-linkages (generated by the d,d-transpeptidase) by 3→3 cross-linkages (generated by an l,d-transpeptidase).(39,40) This substitution is also responsible for the remarkable ability of Mtb to escape digestion by endopeptidases, thus obviating the need for de novo PG synthesis by Mtb.(36)
    Another important feature of mycobacterial PG is that it provides the attachment sites for AG, which is predominantly composed of galactose (Gal) and arabinose (Ara) sugars.(41) About 10–12% of the MurNGlyc residues of PG are covalently attached to AG via a specialized linker unit, α-l-rhamnopyranose-(1→3)-α-d-GlcNAc-(1→P), wherein the C-6 position of the muramyl units provides a site for formation of phosphodiester bonds with the galactan domain of AG.(42) The galactan component of AG is comprised of a linear chain of approximately 30 alternating 5- and 6-linked β-d-Galf residues.(43) Araf residues, approximately 30 units, form highly branched arabinan chains which connect to the linear galactan at the C-5 position of some of the β(1→6) Galf residues.(44) Previously it was suggested that Mtb and the closely related Corynebacterium glutamicum (Cglu) consist of three branched-chain arabinan units connected to the galactan chain at positions 8, 10, and 12.(45,46) However, a recent study proposes that only two arabinan units are attached per galactan chain.(47) The inner core of the arabinan domain contains a backbone of α-5-linked α-d-Araf residues with key branching introduced by 3,5-α-d-Araf residues. Galactosamine and succinyl substituents were subsequently identified on the C-2 position of inner 3,5-α-d-Araf residues.(48,49)
    The Mtb OM and MM, mainly consisting of covalently attached long-chain α-alkyl-β-hydroxy mycolic acid (MA) fatty acids, regulate the fluidity and permeability of the cell envelope. MAs are essential for the survival of mycobacteria and critical for their physiology and fitness.(50−56) There are three distinct types of MA: α-MA are most abundant and exist only in a cis-cyclopropane configuration, whereas methoxy- and keto-MA contain cyclopropane rings in both cis- and trans-configuration with an adjacent methyl branch.(57) MAs are the products of a mixed fatty acid synthase (FAS)/polyketide synthase (PKS) biosynthesis pathway. In Mtb, MA biosynthesis occurs through the coordinated action of more than 20 enzymes that are components of different multi-enzyme complexes and aptly laid the foundation of “activity-based profiling” to identify therapeutically relevant target proteins. Genetic and biochemical studies have revealed most of the PKS family of enzymes to be involved in the biosynthesis of this complex lipid.(58,59) The enoyl-ACP reductase (encoded by inhA gene) of the FAS type II system is a key player in the MA biosynthetic pathway. Mtb contains both type I (FAS I) and type II (FAS II) fatty acid biosynthetic pathways. FAS I is responsible for the de novo synthesis of C16–C26 FAs, while the FAS II system extends these FAs up to C56 to make MA precursors.(60−62) PKS13 plays a critical role in MA biosynthesis in Mtb where it attaches the α-alkyl C26 fatty acid branch (originating from FAS I) and the meromycolic acid (C48–C64) branch (originating from FAS II) through a Claisen-type condensation reaction to form α-alkyl β-ketoacids.(63,64) Consequently, PKS enzymes have been explored as potential drug targets.(65,66) The MAs are synthesized at the IM as trehalose monomycolates (TMMs). The synthesized TMMs are then transported from the IM using mycobacterial membrane protein large (MmpL), belonging to the resistance, nodulation, and division (RND) protein superfamily.(67,68)Mtb genome encodes 13 MmpL proteins, of which MmpL3, -4, -5, -7, -8, -10, and -11 have been reported to be involved in the biosynthesis and transport of the complex cell envelope of mycobacteria.(69) Specifically, MmpL3 is responsible for the translocation of MA in the form of TMM from its production site to the OM.(70,71) Once at the OM, antigen 85 (Ag85) complex (Ag85A, Ag85B, and Ag85C) carries out the biosynthesis of trehalose dimycolate (TDM) and mycolylation of AG from TMMs via transfer of the mycolate chain from one TMM to another to form TDM or to AG to form arabinogalactan mycolate (AGM). While all three AG85 isoforms catalyze transesterification reactions,(72) Backus et al. reported their unique substrate selectivity, wherein Ag85A more efficiently mycolates TMM to form TDM, and 85C (and to lesser extent 85B) has a higher rate of activity to convert free trehalose into TMM.(73) Along similar lines, Ronning et al. elucidated the substrate specificity of AG85A following co-crystallization with suitable substrates.(74) The earliest work of Sathyamoorthy et al. reported the isolation, purification, and characterization of putative trehalose mycolyltransferase from Mycobacterium smegmatis (Msm) that catalyzes MA exchange between trehaloses TMM and TDM.(75) Since then, many similar studies have surfaced and have been extensively tapped for metabolic incorporation of chemical probes for use in mycobacteria. Such studies have inspired probing of Ag85 as an attractive drug target against TB in combination with structural biology.(76−78)

    More Than Just a Permeability Barrier: The Tale of Mycobacterium-Exposed Free Lipids

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Intercalated within the outer leaflet of the MM are non-covalent free atypical lipids such as phthiocerol dimycocerosate (PDIM), trehalose monomycolate (TMM), trehalose dimycolate (TDM), sulfoglycolipids (SLs), polyacyltrehalose (PAT), diacyltrehalose (DAT), mannosyl-β-1-phosphomycoketides (MPM), phosphatidylinositol mannosides (PIMs), lipoarabinomannan (LAM), and free mycolic acid (MA)(31,79) (Figure 1B). These lipids act either via engaging a particular host cell receptor or directly via interaction with the host cell membrane.(80) In the case of former, dedicated bona fide phagocytic receptors such as complement receptors, scavenger receptors, and C-type lectins are involved for recognizing specific lipid classes.(81) For instance, C-type lectins including mannose and DG-SIGN recognize and bind LAMs, while Mincle binds TDM. PILAM and SL-1 are recognized by toll-like receptor (TLR), while DCAR binds to PIMs such as ACPIM2 and AC2PIM2.(81) These lipids can also insert within the host plasma membrane and modify the membrane properties such as lateral organization, lipid domain remodeling, and hydration. These direct or indirect host interactions collectively influence membrane-associated host functions.(14,28,29,82−89) For instance, SL-1, competitive TLR2 antagonist, redistributes ordered lipid domains on macrophage cell surface, modifies the membrane mechanics to impact autophagy and cytokine signaling, disrupts lysosomal machinery, and increases nuclear factor-κB (NF-κB) levels.(14,82−84) LAM modifies raft domains in both model and natural cell membranes preventing membrane fusion, alters the activity of membrane-associated kinases, abrogates TNF-1 secretion, modulates apoptosis, and activates T-cell proliferation.(27,28,85−87) TDM drives mycobacterial phagosome maturation arrest, orchestrates influx of neutrophils to the infection site, and interacts with host cell Mincle receptor to induce IL-12, TNF, and IL6 immune responses by activating Syk-Card9 signaling.(52,88,89) TDM leads to decreased membrane fluidity and enhanced permeability and inhibits Ca2+-induced vesicle fusion, thus hinting toward the phagosome–lysosome fusion machinery as its primary target.(88)
    Though the above findings have clearly improved our understanding of mycobacterial lipids, questions centered around the intracellular fate of these exposed secreted Mtb lipids, their spatiotemporal localization inside the host, and their amenability for therapeutic targeting remain. Further, the vital role of each membrane component in (i) forming a spatially distinct OM-IM permeability barrier and (ii) regulating the overall membrane properties crucial for survival and infection, and (iii) how bacteria use its lipids categorically and their physiological significance, remain hitherto important questions. In this regard, chemical biology-inspired development of synthetic Mtb lipids and precursors can help address some of the above concerns and also enable querying the functional involvement of OM-exposed free lipids during host–pathogen interactions.
    Below, we review chemical tools specific to Mtb membrane components to not only detect Mtb selectively but also illuminate its biology related to pathogenesis, drug resistance, and survival inside the host. Furthermore, many of these tools-driven labeling/detection techniques are amenable to the development of image-based inhibitor screening platforms which are vital in early stages of drug discovery. The subject matter is organized according to the Mtb cell envelope structure.

    Membrane-Focused Chemical Biology Probes for Elucidating Mycobacterial Biology and Diagnosis

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Trehalose-Based Chemical Probes

    The most abundant glycolipids in mycobacterial OM/MM are trehalose glycolipids: TMM and TDM.(71) Because of their prominent role in virulence and bacterial survival, they have served as good platforms for the design of chemical tools to investigate cell membrane biosynthesis, properties, and target trehalose metabolism.(28,52) Moreover, due to their location in the MM, they are the preferred choice for labeling Mtb for visualizing the bacteria. All these have been achieved in vivo by the use of exogenous trehalose and metabolic labeling, leveraging two main bacterial metabolic pathways: SugABC-LpqY and Antigen 85, the latter being more extensively explored.
    Historically, detection of TB has largely relied on culture-based methods.(90) Despite the fact that these are simple and cheap, these are also quite insensitive and unspecific, calling to attention newer and rapid point-of-care diagnostics. Toward this, seminal work by Backus et al. furnished various unnatural and structurally diverse trehalose analogues for improving TB imaging modalities and for probing lipid functions.(91) Particularly, exploiting the Ag85 recycling pathway, uptake of 14C-trehalose was demonstrated for both the in vitro and host-internalized bacteria in infection models, highlighting their in vivo potential. Using ketoside formation and dehydrative glycosylation, precise alteration on the trehalose scaffold was performed that gave way to modified trehalose analogues bearing substituents such as methyl, fluorine, iodine, bromine, phosphate, azide, and amine, including fluorescein-modified FITC-trehalose (FITC-Tre, 1, Figure 2). Mass spectrometry-based screening assays with these probes revealed, for the first time, a high substrate plasticity of Ag85 enzymes during trehalose metabolism. Furthermore, FITC-Tre enabled visualization of live Mtb both in vitro and within infected macrophages, serving as a non-toxic and selective imaging alternative. Using FITC-glucose and mutated Ag85C isoform, incorporation specificity and dependency upon Ag85 was demonstrated. Strain specificity was shown by demonstrating no appreciable labeling of Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus mycolylat and Pseudomonas aeruginosa using 1. The broad substrate tolerance of Ag85 proteins laid the foundation for expansion of metabolic trehalose-based chemical probes for developing new imaging tools as well as investigations into the mycobacterial lipid membrane functions. To this end, Rodriguez-Rivera et al. expanded the trehalose toolkit by introduction of regioisomeric versions of fluorescein-trehalose (FITre, 2a–2d, Figure 2).(92) The rationale behind developing FITre was the use of native trehalose core structure to obviate issues such as inefficient processing by Ag85 complex and some promiscuous labeling in other mycobacterial species encountered by Backus et al. Metabolic incorporation of FITre probes 2a–2d into the trehalose mycolates enabled labeling of trehalose glycolipids in live bacteria followed by investigating the mycobacterial membrane dynamics. Quantification of lipid diffusion afforded by probe 2d-labeled lipids within bacterial MM revealed the membrane fluidity to strongly correlate with the MA structures that varied across the investigated Mycobacterium, Corynebacterium, Nocardia, and Rhodococcus species. This was a first study of its kind that showed a dynamic membrane perturbing effect of the frontline antibiotic, ethambutol, on the mycobacterial membrane, underpinning the applicative potential of probe 2d in drug screening campaigns focused on identification of membrane active agents.
    A major limitation of probes 2a–2d is the high background fluorescence signal inherent with fluorescein chromophore poles.(92−95) The work from the laboratories of Barry, Davis, and Bertozzi has furnished low-background alternatives. First, Kamariza et al. developed a 4-N,N-dimethylamino-1,8-naphthalimide-conjugated trehalose (DMN-Tre, 3, Figure 2).(96) Being an environment-sensitive fluorogenic trehalose, it displayed >700-fold increase in fluorescence intensity upon metabolic conversion of DMN-Tre to TMM and incorporation into the MM. Enhancement of the fluorescence signal overcame the issue of background fluorescence, thus obviating washing steps. Accordingly, probe 3 was successfully demonstrated to label live Mtb in TB-positive sputum samples, offering operationally simple, rapid, and selective clinical TB diagnosis.(96) Fairly recently, application of 3 for use in high-content image-based screening of compounds against intracellular mycobacteria was reported, illustrating the use of trehalose probes for drug screening in in vivo infection models.(97) Second, Rodriguez-Rivera et al. afforded structure–activity screens of regioisomeric trehalose conjugates which enabled synthesis of tetramethylrhodamine (TAMRA) conjugated at the C-6 position on trehalose (6-TMR-Tre, 4, Figure 2) for maximum incorporation efficiency.(98) It was shown to metabolically incorporate into TMM via the Ag85 pathway with strain-specific labeling; no labeling was observed in other bacterial species, such as Bacillus subtilis and Escherichia coli. Further, structured illumination microscopy (SIM) on the metabolized 4 revealed insights into the subcellular organization of TMM, wherein the labeling was mostly concentrated in the polar region of the cells, suggesting specific functional roles of TMM and/or Ag85 proteins at the bacterial poles (Figure 3). Probe 4 not only enabled the first use of super-resolution microscopy of trehalose mycolates in mycobacteria but also seems to possess excellent strain selectivity as well as labeling efficiency.
    The mycomembrane is one of the main targets of the TB clinical regimen; however, alteration of the cell envelope’s physiology in the presence of MM-targeting TB drugs remains poorly understood. Bertozzi and co-workers employed a simultaneous metabolic labeling strategy using probe 4 and a fluorescent d-alanine derivative, NADA (labeling PG), to monitor biosynthetic dynamics and cellular distribution of PG and TMM in Mycobacterium marinum.(98) Their work revealed a rapid and acute modulation of cell envelope biogenesis with subcellular resolution in live bacilli during TB drug exposure, thus establishing trehalose-based reporters as efficient tools to investigate Mtb membrane–drug interactions. Notably, these lipid-focused chemical probes offer excellent alternatives to investigate real-time responses of cell envelope structure to drugs and host environment compared to “static” electron microscopy and vibrational imaging.(98)
    Expanding the scope of trehalose-based probes for real-time imaging of mycobacterial processes and membrane assembly, Hodges et al. developed an “activity-based” probe design that, notably, permitted imaging over several bacterial generations.(99) Exploiting the broad substrate specificity of mycolyltransferases, quencher–trehalose–fluorophore (QTF) probe 5 (Figure 2), based on the natural mycolyltransferase substrate TMM, was developed. In 5, a hydrophobic fluorescent dye, BODIPY-FL, is appended to the terminus of a simplified lipid chain, and the fluorescence quencher DABCYL is linked to the 6′-OH. Only upon mycolyltransferase-mediated hydrolysis in live bacteria, the fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) pair is separated, triggering fluorescence (Figure 4). These ingenious designs thus provided a real-time fluorescent readout of mycolyltransferase activity and MA membrane assembly in a spatiotemporal fashion and revealed the mycolyltransferase activity to be concentrated at bacterial poles and to be cell cycle dependent (Figure 3). Probe 5 reports directly on Ag85 activity, thus making an excellent screening tool for discovery of mycolyltransferase inhibitors. Further, the ability of 5 to rapidly and selectively label mycobacteria in mixed bacterial populations reinforces its utility as a potential TB diagnostic tool.(99)
    Orthogonal to the Ag85 metabolic pathway is the trehalose recycling pathway, in which trehalose is internalized by the SugABC-LpqY transporter and incorporated into glycolipids from the inside of the cytoplasm to the MM/OM via the MmpL3 transport system.(100) It is essential for investigating de novo the biosynthesis of glycolipids, which remains poorly understood due to the lack of trehalose probes accessing this particular pathway. The first report exploiting SugABC-LpqY transporter was achieved by design of azide-modified trehalose analogues 2-TreAZ (6), 3-TreAZ (7), 4-TreAZ (8), and 6-TreAZ (9).(101) Bioorthogonal ligation with alkyne-functionalized probes enabled detection and visualization of cell-surface trehalose-containing glycolipids (Figure 3, probe 9). While probes 6, 8, and 9 labeled trehalose-containing metabolite via the trehalose recycling pathway, 7 accessed the Ag85 pathway, thus providing effective tools for profiling pathway-targeted live mycobacterial “trehalome”.(101) Probes 6 and 9 were found to be more efficient at labeling compared to the other two based on the concentration required (5–25 μM).
    Another set of trehalose probes exploiting the SugABC-LpqY transporter are the chemoenzymatically developed, non-radioactive deoxyfluoro-d-trehalose (19FDTre) analogues (10–13, Figure 2).(102) This study revealed SugABC-LpqY substrate tolerance; probes 19F-2- (10), 19F-3- (11), and 19F-6-FDTre (13) were selectively transferred, while the transfer of 19F-4-FDTre (12) was attenuated. This work was complementary to the earlier work of Backus et al., wherein using a set of fluorinated trehalose compounds with systematically installed 19F at various positions revealed a broad substrate specificity of Ag85 enzymes, unlike the SugABC-LpqY system.(91) Furthermore, the synthetic strategy reported by Rundell et al. could also be leveraged to generate radioactive 18FDTre counterparts, which are of particular interest due to the potential whole-body imaging modality using positron emission tomography (PET) for in vivo imaging of Mtb infections.(102) In fact, recently Peña-Zalbidea et al. developed such 18FDTre compounds and showed successful cellular uptake in Msm but not in mammalian cell lines. These encouraging results imply a successful PET imaging module for monitoring infections caused by trehalose-metabolizing bacterial pathogens such as Mtb.(103) A chemoenzymatic route for synthesizing a trehalose-based probe library was first elucidated by Urbanek et al. using a heat-stable trehalose synthase enzyme, TreT, mirroring the trehalose biosynthesis. The versatility of this method was demonstrated by a one-pot metabolic labeling strategy that included probe synthesis, metabolic labeling, and imaging of Msm.(104)
    Potential issues such as loss in labeling efficiency and off-targets due to trehalose metabolism and isomerization are some foreseeable challenges in the application of the trehalose-based chemical tools presented to date. These are reinforced by the presence of trehalases in both Mtb and humans that could contribute to unwanted trehalose metabolism, forming glucose, and trehalose synthase (TreS), causing isomeric conversion of trehalose to maltose, both leading to loss in labeling.(105−107) As an innovative solution to this problem, a series of asymmetric manno- and galactotrehalose and their 6-azido-modified probes (14 and 15, Figure 2) were developed by Parker et al. that resisted degradation/isomerization by mycobacterial enzymes.(108) Bioorthogonal azide–alkyne “Cu-free” click chemistry revealed their incorporation into the mycobacterial cell envelope via the trehalose recycling pathway. The key finding was that the stereochemical inversion of the 2- and 4-OH groups resulted in hydrolytically highly stable trehalose analogues.(108) This work draws upon the earlier work that revealed an inability of trehalose to enzymatically hydrolyze α,β-trelalose, β,β-trehalose, α-glucoside, and β-glucosides.(109)
    In addition to the sugar-based lipid probes, complementary approaches for investigating the Mtb MM that employ direct lipid-based chemical tools have been developed by Swarts and co-workers. Exploiting the natural mycolyltransferase donor TMM, Foley et al. developed the O/N-Alk-TMM-C7 lipid probes (16 and 17, Figure 2) that harbored a truncated C7 chain containing a clickable terminal alkyne tag.(110) Upon processing by mycolyltransferase (i.e., Ag85) in live cells,(70,76,101) the clickable lipid chain was transferred onto mycolyl acceptors, producing alkyne-labeled arabinogalactan mycolate (AGM) and trehalose dimycolate (TDM), labeling the inner and outer leaflets of the MM, respectively, in a bacterial-strain-specific fashion (Figure 3). This constitutes another study for real-time chemical reporting for mycolylation in intact cells, next to probe 5. The main difference between the two kinds of probes is that, while probe 5 reports directly on Ag85 activity, probes 16 and 17 exploit the Ag85 machinery to label mycolate-containing cell wall components. O-Alk-TMM probes were further explored for functional characterization of proteins involved in the MM assembly, such as LprG and Cglut, as well as to exclusively label O-mycolylated proteins in Cglu and mycobacteria, thus underlining the chemical biology approach for discovery and characterization of distinct classes of proteins involved in cell envelope biogenesis.(110−112)
    Recently, Fiolek et al. expanded the TMM-based reporter toolbox, providing a broader flexibility to investigate MM. They demonstrated an optimal balance of penetration and processing of TMM-based probes by Mtb mycolyltransferase through the use of O-Alk-TMM reporters with varying chain lengths, from C5 to C11 (17, Figure 2).(113) An azide-modified TMM reporter O-AzTMM-C10 (18, Figure 2) was also synthesized to allow non-toxic “Cu-free” click chemistry inside living cells. Further, exceptionally fast and live cell labeling using tetrazine ligation was demonstrated by developing a trans-cyclooctene-modified TMM reporter, O-TCO-TMM (19, Figure 2). Finally, a fluorescein-modified TMM reporter, O-FITC-TMM (20, Figure 2), enabled one-step labeling of live mycobacterial cells with strain specificity (i.e., no labeling was seen for B. subtilis and E. coli, Figure 3). Collectively, their work provided a platform for in-depth evaluation of mycolylation substrate tolerance for varying size and polarity of the tag.(113) Drawing upon the above substrate tolerance, specifically related to the acyl chain lengths, recently Kavunja et al. showcased the utility of N-and O-Alk-TMM-C15 probes for identifying mycolate-binding protein in a native MM environment.(114) Installing photoactivable clickable motifs onto their previous MM-targeting TMM probes, they developed bifunctional N- and O-x-Alk-TMM-C15 probes (21 and 22, Figure 2). Photoactivatable diazirine enabled covalent cross-linking to lipid-binding proteins, and the clickable alkyne facilitated subsequent affinity enrichment and proteomic target identification. This is the first study detailing the use of Mtb lipid chemical probes to map the landscape of lipid-binding proteins in mycobacteria with immense potential for discovery of mycolate-associated proteins involved in host–pathogen interactions, as diagnostic markers as well as vaccine candidates. The work revealed identification of up to 110 proteins from Msm, including known trehalose mycolate interacting proteins—justifying the robust probe design and potentially novel MM-remodeling proteins, which await further functional validation.(114)
    In addition to the probes monitoring Ag85-catalyzed TDM biosynthesis, tools targeting mycobacterial TDM hydrolase (Tdmh) that catabolizes TDM also constitute a comprehensive toolkit to investigate MM remodeling responses under stressed conditions, e.g., upon drug interaction or inside the host. This is attributed to findings that reveal upregulation of Tdmh activity under nutrient deprivation, leading to a more permeable cell membrane. This lowers bacterial defense and heightens the bacterial response to stresses. Homes et al., by developing a fluorescence-quenched analogue of TDM (FRET-TDM, 23, Figure 2), directly monitored Tdmh activity in vitro and in live cells.(115)23 possesses a TDM mimicking core with two C10 chains, functionalized at their terminal with fluorescein and dabcyl (as a quencher, highlighted in 23). A 100-fold increase in fluorescence was observed upon enzymatic processing, enabling direct bacteria visualization—a potential diagnostic tool. The major drawback of 23 is its processing by other mycobacterial enzymes, implying non-specificity (and non-selective labeling of other bacterial species). Nonetheless, 23 is expected to inspire assay development for identifying potential Tdmh inhibitors and to facilitate identification of other hydrolases that are involved in MM remodeling due to its non-specific substrate nature.(115)

    Arabinose-Based Chemical Probes

    In addition to trehalose, d-arabinose is another essential sugar component of the mycobacterial cell envelope. d-Arabinose occurs in two isomeric forms, d-arabinopyranose and d-arabinofuranose. AG and LAM formation involves the arabinosyl residues from decaprenyl-phospho-d-arabinofuranose.(116) With the initial aim of identifying novel biosynthetic pathways for cell wall arabinosylation, Kolbe et al. designed new compounds for labeling Mtb as azido-pentoses, including 3-azidoarabinose (3AraAz, 24), 3-azidoribose (3RiboAz, 25), and 5-azidoarabinofuranose (5AraAz, 26), and showed them to metabolically and selectively label clinical Mtb isolates (Figure 5).(117) Of particular interest was the finding that the presumed negative control probe 26, which should have prevented an essential step in the known arabinan metabolism, was also incorporated into the cell wall. This signifies the presence of an unknown carbohydrate biosynthetic pathway and presumably novel pentose transporters for arabinose derivate uptake; however, confirmation awaits further investigations. At present, the direct labeling targets and transporters of these probes are not known. The need for higher working concentrations of 26 for Mtb labeling severely limits its application for in vivo imaging.(117)

    Peptidoglycan-Targeting Amino Acid-Based Probes

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Unnatural amino acids have been successfully applied to visualize peptidoglycan (PG) dynamics, structure, and biogenesis in vivo across various bacterial species.(118−120) In this regard, the seminal work from the group of VanNieuwenhze on fluorescent d-amino acids (FDAAs) has enriched the knowledge on the formation and remodeling of PG in both Gram-positive and -negative bacterial species as well as elucidating the mode of action of cell-wall-targeting antibiotics by capitalizing on the development of diverse non-natural functionalized amino acids targeting bacterial PG.(121−123) Indeed, this body of work laid the foundation for extending the scope of such PG labeling tools in mycobacteria as detailed below.
    PG is an important constituent of the mycobacterial cell envelope, as described above in detail.(35,38) Alanine racemase (Alr) and d-Ala-d-Ala ligase catalyze the first and the second committed steps in bacterial PG biosynthesis, respectively.(124) Alr is a pyridoxal 5′-phosphate-containing enzyme that catalyzes the racemization of l-alanine into d-alanine, a major component in the biosynthesis of PG. d-Alanine-d-alanine ligase (Ddl) is involved in joining two d-alanine residues together by catalyzing the formation of an ATP-dependent d-alanine-d-alanine dipeptide bond.(125,126)d-Cycloserine has been shown to inhibit both of these enzymes during PG synthesis, which together with promiscuous PG enzymatic pathways suggest application of unnatural d-amino acids for PG labeling (Figure 6).(125) Metabolic labeling-enabled visualization of mycobacterial PG was achieved by employing azide- and alkyne-functionalized unnatural d-alanine derivatives (azDala, (R)-2-amino-3-azidopropanoic acid, 27, and alkDala, (R)-propargylglycine, 28, respectively, Figure 6) in a wide variety of bacterial species (E. coli, Listeria monocytogenes, Cglu, and Mtb).(127) Exogenous d-alanine suppressed the labeling by 27 and suggests the incorporation of probes 27 and 28 to be mediated by the same metabolic pathway as for the natural d-alanine. The authors reported specific labeling of L. monocytogenes within macrophages with probe 28 and fluorescent dye azido-Fluor 488 for monitoring PG dynamics during infection. This study expands the unnatural substrate tolerance in d-alanine metabolism, which can be exploited to monitor PG biosynthesis.(127)
    Using super-resolution imaging and fluorescent d-alanine probes, 7-nitrobenzofurazan coupled to 3-amino-d-alanine (NADA, 29, Figure 6) and 7-hydroxycoumarin-3-carboxylic acid coupled to 3-amino-d-alanine (HADA, 30, Figure 6), Botella et al. investigated spatiotemporal dynamics of PG formation.(128) Their key findings were that (i) PG elongation substantially differs in Msm and Mtb, (ii) bacterial septum formation progresses through concentric incorporation of PG from outer to inner layers, and (iii) the drug, Meropenem, influences closure of the dividing septum during cytokinesis, in contrast to previously thought septum formation. A higher incorporation of 29 and 30 at one pole in Msm suggests asymmetrical elongation of PG from one preferred pole (Figure 3). This was consistent with previous reports that used fluorescently labeled vancomycin to demonstrate a unipolar localization of de novo-synthesized PG in Mtb.(128)
    Expanding on the PG-based chemical probes, a novel near-infrared (NIR) imaging probe, DLF-1 (31, Figure 6) was developed and used for detection of Mtb in dormant and replicative states, both in vitro and in vivo (Figure 3).(129)31 is composed of vancomycin and fluorescent dye Cy5.5, with high binding affinity toward the terminal peptide of d-Ala-d-Ala in PG.(129) Bertozzi and co-workers developed another PG-targeting NIR fluorogenic approach with high tissue penetrance and low background, using a series of fluorogenic azido Si-rhodamine compounds.(130) Probe 32, together with cyclooctyne-functionalized d-alanine probe 33 (Figure 6), furnished no-wash, live imaging of PG in Msm, Cglut, and L. monocytogenes. Although untested, use of this technique for in vivo imaging of PG in pathogenic bacteria during infection should be possible.(130)
    Consistent with the functional role of l,d-transpeptidase (Ldt) in PG biosynthesis, Pidgeon et al. developed Ldt-specific probes, followed by their metabolic incorporation into PG with an aim to monitor Ldt activity during PG cross-linking.(131) Specifically, fluorescent dye was attached onto the N-terminus of the tetrapeptide PG mimic, furnishing TetraFl, with addition of terminal d-Ala to TetraFl giving PentaFl. Both of these probes, along with TetraRh (tetrapeptide linked with rhodamine, 34, Figure 6), were used for labeling PG for bacterial detection and for evaluating real-time PG cross-linking alterations in the presence of Meropenem (Figure 3).(131)
    PG synthesis has been a long-standing drug target, and now the use of chemical probes for monitoring of PG assembly can further facilitate identification of new targets, in addition to rationalizing the mode of action of current anti-mycobacterial drugs. Figure 7 summaries the chemical biology approaches for metabolic labeling of Mtb cell surface (relying on trehalose, arabinose, and amino acids) by exploiting targetable metabolic pathways and associated players. The chemical probes inspired by bacterial sugars and amino acids for Mtb cell surface labeling are summarized in Table 1.
    Table 1. Chemical Probes Inspired by Bacterial Sugars and Amino Acids for Mtb Cell Surface Labeling
    probeprobe starting scaffoldprobe targetapplications
    FITC-trehalose(91)(1)trehaloseMM, TMMdetection of live Mtb in infected macrophages
    6-FITre(92)(2d)trehaloseMM, TMMdetection of live Mtb and membrane-drug interactions
    DMN-Tre(96,97)(3)trehaloseMM, TMMdetection of Mtb in sputum, high content inhibitor screening
    6-TMR-Tre(98)(4)trehaloseMM, TMMdetection of live Mtb and drug–membrane interaction
    QTF(99)(5)trehalosemycoyltransferasedetection of live Mtb in mixed populations, read-out of mycolyltransferase
    TreAZ analogues(101,104)(6–9)trehaloseMMdetection of live Mtb, visualization of cell-surface trehalose-containing glycolipids
    FDTre analogues(102,103)(10–13)trehaloseMM, TMMprobable potential use in PET imaging
    O-Alk-TMM(110)(17)trehaloseAG-linked mycolatedetection of live Mtb, chemical reporting for mycolylation in intact cells, functional characterization of O-mycolyated proteins
    O-TCO-TMM(113)(19)trehaloseAG-linked mycolatedetection of live Mtb
    N/O-x-AlkTMM-C15(114)(21, 22)trehaloseN-x-AlkTMM-C15 labels TDM, whereas O-x- AlkTMM-C15 labels TDM and AGMdetection of live Msm, mapping mycobacterial lipid binding proteins
    FRET-TDM(115)(23)trehaloseTDM hydrolasedetection of live Mtb, discovery of TDM hydrolase inhibitors
    5AraAz(117)(26)pentoseAGlabeling clinical Mtb isolates, cell surface labeling
    AlkDala (27), AzDala(127)(28)d-alaninePGPG labeling, dynamic studies
    NADA(128)(29)d-alaninePGmonitoring PG biosynthesis
    DLF-1(129)(31)vancomycinPGdetection of Mtb in dormant and replicative states in vitro and in vivo
    cyclooctyne-functionalized probes(130)(33)d-alaninePGin vivo PG imaging, detection of live Mtb
    TetraRh(131)(34)tetrapeptidetranspeptidasedetection of live Mtb, real-time monitoring of PG biosynthesis

    Lipid Probes Targeting Membrane-Centric Host–Pathogen Interactions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Chemical tools that label mycobacterial lipid membrane components (such as trehalose-based) have been successfully employed for investigation of mycobacterial membranes dynamics, bacterial detection, and identification and subsequently functional elucidation of proteins involved in cell envelope biogenesis.(27,30) However, their use to investigate host–pathogen interactions has not been explored.(28,29) This severely limits our understanding of the intricate interactome of the host–pathogen crosstalk. In a recent review, Kolbe et al. consistently pointed out that the tools of chemical biology are still to find utility in answering the most basic steps of TB infection, i.e., how the pathogen interacts with its host, particularly the host membrane—the first point of pathogenic contact.(24) In this direction, only a handful of studies using natural or synthetic mycobacterial virulent lipids have emerged in the past few years and merit listing here to not only inform the future development of suitable tool compounds but also bring the scientific community abreast with recent developments in this field.
    Though mycobacterial proteins have held the center stage in the studies focused on host interactions, the notion of involvement of virulent lipids from mycobacterial species is quite prevalent. Among various Mtb lipids, the free exposed lipids within the MM (Figure 1) are of particular interest due to their location that predisposes them to interact with the host cell membrane.(80,82,84) These surface-exposed lipids influence host functions either by binding to the host membrane receptors or, upon insertion, by altering the biophysical properties of the host membranes (largely understudied). The latter modulates host-membrane-associated cellular signaling and trafficking events.(29,14) Thus, mycobacteria adopts a lipid-centric approach to maneuver its entry into the host, followed by specific alteration of various host processes to aid infection and survival. Some of the MM-exposed Mtb lipids and their mechanisms of action are discussed below.
    Pthiocerol dimycocerosate (PDIM) is a widely investigated Mtb lipid associated with virulence; see Figure 1.(132,133) The mode of action of DIM/PDIM includes modulation of phagocytosis and its correlation to cholesterol-linked complement receptor 3 (CR3).(133) PDIM directly affects the biophysical properties of the host membrane upon interaction—a field rapidly gaining attention.(80,133−135) PDIM incorporates into the host membrane and modulates its organization by increasing membrane rigidity.(133) Recently, Augenstriech et al. corroborated the incorporation of PDIM into the host THP-1 cell membrane by MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry(135) The mechanism involves direct insertion of free PDIM into the host membrane; vesicle-mediated transfer and/or endocytosis may also be involved. Using molecular modeling and 31P NMR, it was revealed that PDIM adopts a conical shape in host membranes while aggregating in the stalks between two opposing lipid bilayers, leading to the formation of inverted hexagonal lipid structures that act as fusion intermediates. The conical shape of PDIM thus enables the vesicle to attain the required curvature for the formation of fusion intermediates and finally the fusion with the host membrane.(136) It has already been reported that the formation of non-bilayer structures is associated with a facile fusion process.(137) Moreover, infection of macrophages pre-treated with lipids of various shapes uncovered a general role for conical lipids in promoting phagocytosis. Thus, the conical shape of PDIM and its effect on disorganizing the membrane may play roles in the already reported induction of phagosomal membrane rupture and apoptosis.(134)
    As many Mtb lipids are known to extend their pathogenic effect via interaction of their sugar moiety with the target receptors,(29) the lack of a polysaccharide unit in PDIM implies that its molecular mechanism involves alteration of host cell membrane physical properties including fluidity, membrane order, and hydration. Aligning with this, Augenstriech et al. investigated the membrane perturbation by PDIM using polarity-sensitive fluorophores and multiphoton microscopy.(138) A decrease in the membrane polarity at the site of contact between the bacilli and host membranes was observed. Since PDIM induces membrane curvature, this enhances the activity of membrane-associated proteins CR3 (receptor for Mtb phagocytosis) and EsxA (virulence factor). In summary, PDIM reorganizes the host lipid organization, which influences the activity of host cell receptors and subsequently rewires host-signaling pathways.(139)
    In another work, Mishra et al. studied the effect of sulfoglycolipid-1 (SL-1) on the host cell membrane. SL-1, a tetra-acylated glycolipid, is the most abundant sulfatide in Mtb OM (Figure 1).(82) SL-1 features a sulfated trehalose headgroup with four acyl chains with CH3 branches with unique stereochemistry. It is expressed in the virulent strains of Mtb and is also present as a non-covalently bound free lipid on the OM surface.(15) Mishra et al. specifically addressed the ability of SL-1 to alter host cell membrane properties, akin to PDIM, to validate the host cell membrane insertion as a “generic” mode of action of Mtb virulent lipids.(82) The authors characterized the biophysical, nanomechanical, and cell biological properties of live THP-1 macrophage cell membranes upon insertion of SL-1. Using two-photon microscopy and an environment-sensitive membrane dye, Laurdan, remodeling of the host cell plasma membrane in live macrophages by SL-1 was demonstrated. Specifically, SL-1 redistributed ordered raft-like lipid domains on the THP-1 cell surface in a temporal fashion while increasing the cell membrane fluidity. Further, SL-1 decreased the elastic modulus of the host cell membrane by approximately 2-fold, as revealed by atomic force microscopy. Next, a selective perturbation of the underlying actin cytoskeleton by SL-1 without any effects on the cell viability was also documented. Finally, demonstrating a modified autophagy signaling profile revealed the functional consequences of such host membrane perturbations. Collectively, these findings show that SL-1 lipid present in the mycobacteria is involved in host cell membrane interactions and responsible for alteration of the membrane-associated cellular functions in infected cells. As a follow-up on cytoskeletal modulation by SL-1, Mishra et al. recently elucidated the functional involvement of host signaling lipid PIP(4,5)2 during the crosstalk of SL-1 and host cells; the identity of other implicated host partners is not known.(140)
    The above studies highlight the unmet need for developing suitable synthetic Mtb lipids, attributed to the synthetically intractable nature of natural Mtb lipids and limited extractable amounts required for performing any biological studies. In this regard, for the first time, Dadhich et al., while addressing the above concerns, adopted a chemical biology approach and designed synthetic analogues of SL-1 (35–37, Figure 8).(14) These analogues take inspiration from the SL-1-centric toolkit being developed to generate non-natural Mtb lipids.(141) The study by Dadhich et al. explored the functional role of specific chemical moieties within the SL-1 lipid structure (such as sulfate ion and acyl chains) during host membrane interactions. Biophysics, cell biology, and molecular dynamics simulations experiments elucidated a direct correlation between host membrane structure modification and modulation of membrane-associated signaling pathways. Their key findings revealed that (i) synthetic SL-1 bearing shorter acyl chains displayed a similar host membrane alteration as the natural SL-1—in fact, similar bioactivity of the simplified SL-1 analogue has been reported;(15,142) (ii) the FA acyl chains at the 6,6′-trehalose position are crucial for membrane ordering during infection; and (iii) the sulfate group has a role in blocking autophagosome maturation and modulating host autophagy flux during signaling. At the moment, a simplified probe design of SL-1 analogues may lead to additional biological activity and mandate further investigations. In addition, simulations revealed SL-1 to have distinct conformational states of its acyl chains that markedly differed from other Mtb lipids. This underpins the observed differences in biologic output observed with various Mtb lipids. A mechanism whereby Mtb uses specific chemical moieties on its lipids to fine-tune host–lipid interactions and regulate the downstream host signaling by modifying cell membrane structure and function was postulated. These findings are expected to inspire development of chemotherapeutics against Mtb by counteracting the effects of Mtb lipids on the host cell membrane.(14)
    Given the impact of these studies, development of a synthetic lipid toolkit for probing host interactions merits further research. Such probes can enable investigation of distinct chemical aspects of the virulent Mtb lipid structure, to monitor the fate of host-internalized Mtb lipids as well as to identify host proteins involved in the Mtb–host landscape. We believe careful investigations into the structure–function relationships of synthetic Mtb lipids would inform the development of Mtb lipid probes that harbor suitable NIR fluorescent or clickable moieties. This can be achieved by capitalizing through novel synthetic chemistry strategies unknown metabolic labeling routes for relevant Mtb lipids. In this regard, a potential limitation that may surface is the de-regulation of lipid biophysical properties, localization, and function due to the relatively large chemical modifications to the lipid in question. An innovative solution to this can be installation of small functional groups such as C–C triple bond, N3, etc. (relative to bulky fluorophore), which reside in the biological silent regions, and the use of Raman imaging. This can enable real-time monitoring of various classes of Mtb lipids bearing alkynes and dynes in living systems to explore membrane-centric biological processes in the host–pathogen landscape otherwise invisible to fluorescence imaging.

    Protein-Based Chemical Biology Probes in Mycobacteria

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Activity-Based Chemical Probes for Mycobacterial Enzyme Identification and Drug Screening

    Mycobacteria synthesize a large number of proteins for regulating specific processes such as biosynthesis and adaptation of its cell envelope, hijacking and modulation of host cellular processes, and transport of virulent effector lipids to the outer surface; hence, they are attractive drug targets in TB drug discovery.(143) Chemical biology approaches for identification and validation of potential drug targets and discovery and design of small lead molecules rely on the development of activity- and affinity-based probes, known as ABP and AfBP, respectively.(22,144) In ABP profiling (ABPP), molecular probes with activity tailored toward the active site of diverse enzyme classes are designed to unravel their activity and function.(145) ABPs harbor a reactive functional group that irreversibly binds to the protein active sites. On the other hand, AfBP profiling entails devolvement of probes that show affinity for a specific protein binding site (not necessarily the active site), followed by a tunable covalent bond-forming event, such as UV irradiation of photo-cross-linking groups including diazirines, azides, and benzophenones.(146) In general, both ABPs and AfBPs consist of three distinct functional elements: a reactive group for covalent attachment to the protein, a linker that can modulate reactivity and specificity of the reactive group, and a tag for identification and purification of the modified protein. The tag can be either a fluorescent or biotin group bound directly to the chemical probe, or clickable moieties that enable tandem labeling strategies in cell extract or live cells.(147) Following successful incorporation of these chemical probes, the tag permits characterization of protein hits using imaging, gel electrophoresis, or mass spectroscopy.(144,148) Such probes have served as potent tools for identification/validation of the targets (and off-targets), for aiding the development of high-throughput screening against validated targets, and for general protein labeling as well as proteomics in various disease models. Here we review mycobacterial enzyme-specific chemical tools for selective labeling of Mtb and diagnosis by exploiting bacterial native enzyme functions.
    Adenylating enzymes are one of the most desirable drug targets in TB due to their involvement in a number of essential biochemical processes. Mtb encodes more than 60 adenylating enzymes, of which 34 are fatty acid adenylating enzymes (FadDs) that play key roles in mycobacterial lipid metabolism.(149,150) The lipid biosynthesis pathway in mycobacteria generates complex natural lipids including MAs, PDIM, phenolic glycolipids, and mycobactins.(58) The mycolic acid synthase enzyme FadD28 is of particular interest due to its involvement in synthesis of virulent lipids, along with being the only Mtb FaD that is structurally characterized and hence suitable for structure-based drug development. Using FadD28 bisubstrate inhibitor, Grimes et al. developed an active-site-directed fluorescent probe, tetradecanoyl-AMS-TAMRA (38, Figure 9), and concomitantly established a high-throughput fluorescence polarization assay to identify small-molecule inhibitors against FaD28.(151) Another class of interesting adenylating enzymes are those involved in the synthesis of small-molecule metabolites such as iron-sequestering mycobactins (Mbt, 39, Figure 9). Multistep biosynthesis of Mbt is initiated by adenylate enzyme (MbtA) through activation of the salicylic acid to form an acyl-adenylate intermediate (Sal-AMP).(152) Based on the structure of this intermediate, Aldrich’s group and others have developed Sal-AMS (40, Figure 9) as a potent nanomolar bisubstrate inhibitor of MbtA, which also shows excellent antitubercular activity. Interestingly, this inhibitor shows good minimum inhibitory concentration under both iron-deficient and iron-replete conditions, which points toward possible off-targets of 40. This is due to the fact that Mbt biosynthesis is not required under the above conditions. Hence, in order to generate a comprehensive understanding of the mechanism of action (MoA) of 40 in Mtb, Aldrich’s group designed an affinity-based probe for MbtA, Sal-AMS AfBP (41). Based on the favorable structure–activity relationship at the C-2 position of the adenosine ring, the authors decided to attach benzophenone as the photoreactive group at that position, furnishing 41, followed by attaching clickable alkyne as the reporter motif (Figure 9).(153) This probe displayed appreciable affinity toward MbtA, both in vitro and inside Mtb. Moreover, its protein interactions were inhibited by pre-incubation with 40, suggesting probe 41 to be a good candidate for proteomic profiling and also for specific labeling. The discovery of probe 41 provides a prototypical core scaffold for the creation of AfBPs to profile other adenylating enzymes in Mtb or even in other pathogenic bacteria.(153)
    There are many potential target enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of the unique cell wall of Mtb. Hence, it is important to have access to a high-throughput assay for screening their potential inhibitors. One such enzyme and a promising drug target is Mtbl,d-transpeptidase (LdtMt2). With a set of enzymatically activable fluorogenic probes (42, 43, Figure 9), a high-throughput screening (HTS) against LdTMt2 was established.(154) LdtMt2 has a cysteine residue in its active site, which reacts with the cysteine-specific fluorogenic probe to release the fluorophore. The assay rationale was that the impact of inhibitors on the availability of the catalytic site could be measured through the irreversible reaction of the active-site cysteine with a fluorogenic probe, providing a “non-classical” inhibition assay (Figure 9). A variety of thiol-reactive fluorogenic compounds were studied, from which benzoxadiazole (42) and fluorescein (43) probes were selected on the basis of their reactivity. Further evaluation showed the assay to be more sensitive using probe 43, whereas 42 was found to be hydrolytically more stable, which could be advantageous while assaying reactive inhibitors. The HTS revealed penems and carbapenems as the most potent classes of inhibitors against LdtMt2, bringing the β-lactam antibiotics back in focus for informing the design of future chemical probes. Together with HTS, this fluorogenic assay can be applied for the identification of new chemical templates as Ldt inhibitors as well as for the lead optimization of β-lactams for the treatment of TB.(154)
    UDP-galactopyranose mutase (UGM or Galf) is the only enzyme that catalyzes the isomerization of UDP-galactopyranose (UDP-Galp) to UDP-Galf;(155,156) Galf is a critical constituent of the mycobacterial cell wall AG, crucial for mycobacterial viability. This suggests that the enzymes involved in its biosynthesis, including UGM, might serve as valuable therapeutic targets.(157) Toward this end, Carlson et al. developed a high-throughput fluorescence polarization screening assay using a fluorescent uridine diphosphate (UDP) derivative (44, Figure 9) to identify new ligands of UGM.(158) Though this study was in vitro, it may serve as a relevant starting point to develop ABPP strategies centered on UGM.
    Finally, given the importance of ATP-binding proteins, it is of paramount importance to not only annotate but also validate the plethora of in silico protein function annotations available for the Mtb genome.(159−162) In this direction, Ansong et al. developed an active-site-directed ATP-ABP chemical probe (45, Figure 9) to annotate and validate ATP-binding proteins in Mtb. They combined ABPP and quantitative liquid chromatography–tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS)-based proteomics to establish an experimental annotation platform. Mechanistically, the ε-amino group of Lys residues of proteins reacts with one of two acyl phosphate moieties on the probe 45, leading to the transfer of alkyne with the release of ATP (Figure 9). In the next step, these proteins are trapped through click chemistry using a reporter carrying an azide tag. Probing the Mtb proteome for binding with the probe 45, the authors confirmed the predictions of >240 ATP-binding proteins and identified 72 hypothetical proteins as ATP-binding proteins, including proteins essential to ESX-1 secretion, a major virulence determinant of Mtb. A total of 317 ATP-binding proteins were identified using this method.(163) This approach truly exemplifies the potential of ABP probes in deciphering novel biology of Mtb.

    Enyzme-Based Chemical Probes for Clinical Diagnosis of Mtb

    Decaprenylphosphoryl-β-d-ribose 2′-epimerase 1 (DprE1) is therapeutically interesting due to its essentiality for maintaining the integrity of the Mtb cell envelope by aiding in the synthesis of AG-PG building block, arabinofuranose.(164−167) Consistently, multiple drug discovery programs have discovered at least 11 different chemical scaffolds which bind DprE1. Among these, the benzothiazinones constitute the most promising class of compounds. Compounds PBTZ 169 (46) and BTZ 043 (47) are currently in clinical trials for the treatment of TB. Benzothiazinones are irreversible inhibitors of DprE1 that require activation of an aromatic nitro group for antitubercular activity.(166) Mycobacterium reduces the nitro aromatic group into nitrosoarene, and the nitroso group then reacts with an active cysteine residue of DprE1 to form a semimercaptal adduct, covalently binding to and inactivating the enzyme.(168,169) Thus, small molecules targeting DprE1 have the potential to not only attenuate bacterial growth due to the incomplete cell wall but also serve as tool compounds to design various probes to (a) tag DprE1 for functional analysis and (b) investigate subcellular localization of DrpE1. This hypothesis was tested early on during the MoA studies of these compounds when Rao and co-workers synthesized the fluorophore-tagged analogue of BTZ043, BTZ-TAMRA (48, Figure 10), to reveal the subcellular localization of DprE1 at the bacterial poles. Interestingly, the probe also displayed appreciable anti-mycobacterial activity.(170) To expand this scope, Sommer et al. employed probe 48 as the starting point to further optimize the anti-mycobacterial property of this class of compounds as well as to evaluate their potential as imaging agents in vitro and in vivo. Six new fluorescent BTZ and PBTZ analogues were designed, with JN108 (49, Figure 10) being the most promising probe, having excellent anti-bactericidal activity against various mycobacterial strains. 49 enabled insights into multiple biological phenomena associated with DprE1, including its selectivity of binding, subcellular localization (Figure 12), and role in tip expansion at the poles as well as at budding locations in branching bacteria. 49 also labeled the cell-free extracts as well as live Mtb cells.(171) Finally, this study, while establishing 49 as the best probe for studying DprE1, also provided a range of different fluorophores that can be successfully incorporated into the BTZ scaffold class. The development of BTZ-inspired probes is a classic example of the structural knowledge generated during medicinal chemistry efforts to enable good quality chemical probes for functional as well as labeling studies.
    β-Lactam—the most celebrated class of antibiotics—impedes the enzyme d,d-transpeptidase that is responsible for the formation of the PG layer and consequently inhibits cell wall synthesis.(172) Bacteria often develop resistance to this class of antibiotics through increased expression of a bacterial enzyme, β-lactamase, that inactivate such antibiotics(173) by hydrolyzing the β-lactam ring.(174)Mtb is intrinsically resistant to almost all β-lactam antibiotics because of the production of a promiscuous and shielded β-lactamase named BlaC; the lipid anchor of BlaC localizes it to the outer leaflet of the IM of the mycobacteria.(175,176) Rao’s group made a seminal contribution in the area by exploiting the activity of BlaC through their series of fluorogenic probes. In the early phase of their research in this area, they developed cephalosporin-based NIR fluorogenic substrates for β-lactamase, including CNIR5 (50, Figure 10), that allowed real-time imaging of pulmonary infection and non-invasive detection of pulmonary TB in mice.(177) Mechanistically, the NIR probes are non-fluorescent due to FRET between the quencher and the active moiety. Upon incubation with Mtb, BlaC-mediated cleavage triggers spontaneous fragmentation of lactam ring by releasing the quencher connected to 3′ position of the lactam, thus inhibiting FRET and restoring fluorescence. This enables real-time detection of Mtb infection (Figure 12) and also establishes BlaC as a promising diagnostic avenue in TB. Despite validation of 50 as a highly useful probe for labeling Mtb, it suffers from two major drawbacks: first, it lacks specificity for Mtb BlaC over the common TEM-1 Bla found in Gram-negative bacteria (which can also generate fluorescence, leading to non-specific labeling), and second, due to their large structure, these probes including 50 display slow hydrolytic kinetics, resulting in longer detection times.(177)
    In order to overcome these limitations, Xie et al. employed a structure-based rational design of a structurally different class of β-lactam cephalosporin-based fluorogenic substrates (CDC-OME, 51, Figure 10) by taking advantage of the flexibility of the BlaC substrate-specificity loop.(178) They hypothesized that structural variation in the probe would increase the hydrolytic kinetics by Mtb BlaC over TEM-1 Bla and, hence, could render specificity. Enzymatic kinetics studies with probe 51 indeed revealed the specificity for BlaC through a 30-fold enhancement in fluorescence within 30 min, as compared to no such enhancement for TEM-1 Bla. The structural origin of the observed specificity was also established based on the crystal structures. The low sensitivity of 51 to label some Mtb species paved the way for CDG-OME (52), wherein the umbelliferone fluorophore was replaced with Tokyo Green. Probe 52 displayed improved BlaC specificity and was able to reasonably detect Mtb in sputum samples, demonstrating its potential for clinical TB diagnosis. In fact, 52 has been tested for diagnostic application in low-resource settings, wherein a handmade box equipped with a simple LED light source, excitation filter, and emission filter was used for detecting samples having 10 cfu of Bacillus calmette guerin (BCG) in 200 mL of human sputum. Interestingly, 52 could readily detect bacteria at this low concentration. This suggests the applicability of 52 as a sensitive and specific probe for detecting Mtb var. bovis strain BCG in clinical specimens at a relatively low cost.(178) To further improve Bla detection specificity, a CDG-3 probe (53, Figure 10) was developed wherein a cyclopropyl group was introduced in the lactam ring of probe 52. The rationale for development of 53 was the big cavity of BlaC that could potentially tolerate bulkier substitution on the lactam ring. On hydrolysis with BlaC, 53 generated a 214-fold increase in fluorescence in comparison to probe 52. 53 was able to detect Mtb in unprocessed human sputum in the presence of high levels of other clinically relevant bacteria. Interestingly, 53 also detected Mtb in clinical samples wherein TB-positive samples could be detected with 90% sensitivity and TB-negative with 73% specificity.(179) Very recently, Rao and co-workers developed a cephalosporinase-dependent and MM-targeting fluorogenic probe (CDG-Tre, 53a, Figure 10) for specific tracking of phagocytosed mycobacteria. 53a fluoresces upon activation by BlaC, and the fluorescent product is installed within the bacterial cell wall via Ag85 trehalose metabolic pathway labeling the MM (see Figure 12). This probe was also shown to selectively label Msm but not C. diphtheriae; the latter lacks the ability to activate 53a. Finally, 53a labeled live BCG phagocytosed within macrophages in addition to labeling clinically relevant mycobacterial strains (Figure 12).(180)
    After successfully developing a series of BlaC-enabled fluorogenic probes for highly specific and sensitive detection of Mtb, Rao’s group evolved the cephalosporin-conjugated fluorogenic probes for dual targeting of BlaC and DprE1, with an initial aim to further enhance the specificity for Mtb detection.(181) In order to accomplish this, various analogues of electron-deficient nitroaromatic DprE1 inhibitors having different fluorophores were synthesized and studied in recombinant Msm DprE1 (DprE1SM). It was observed that TG-DNB1 (54, Figure 11) and TG-DNB2 (55) both exhibited distinct fluorescence labeling only in microorganisms having DprE1 expression, such as Msm and C. diphtheriae. Building on these findings, a dual targeting strategy was applied, which rendered probes CDG-DNB1 (56) and CDG-DNB2 (57). When the labeling study was carried out in the presence of a β-lactamase inhibitor (clavulanic acid) and DprE1 inhibitor (DNB1), a 60% decrease in the fluorescent signals in Msm was obtained, demonstrating the dual targeting mechanism of probes 56 and 57 (Figure 11). Probe 57 was further evaluated for labeling in live BCG in sputum samples from patients, where it showed emerald green fluorescence in TB-positive specimens. These findings suggest the diagnostic potential of CDG-DNB probes. Their entire dual targeting probe collection has three functional units: a BlaC-sensing unit, a caged fluorescence reporter, and a DprE1-binding moiety (Figure 11). Further enhancement of the specificity of dual targeting probes for Mtb over other mycobacterial species was achieved using CDG-DNB3 (58, Figure 11), wherein a methoxy substitution in the lactam ring at the 7 position was introduced in probe 57. 58 displayed no affinity toward TEM-1 Bla, while maintaining high affinity toward BlaC. Importantly, 58 exhibited excellent labeling selectivity toward Mtb compared to 45 live non-tuberculosis mycobacteria (NTM) strains and could also label live BCG inside infected macrophages (Figure 12). This laid the foundation for development of a self-driven microfluidic chip to count the number of CDG-DNB3-stained Mtb. This rapid, non-invasive, specific labeling and counting of live Mtb positions 58 as a potentially powerful probe for investigating the pathogenesis as well as for diagnosis of TB.(181)
    In an attempt to detect different mycobacterial strains using enzyme probes, Beatty et al. developed a sulfatase-based fluorogenic probe (DDAO-sulfate, 7-hydroxy-9H-(1,3-dichloro-9,9-dimethylacridin-2-one)-sulfate, 59, Figure 13).(182) DDAO-sulfate detected enzyme activity in native protein gels, thus allowing for the rapid detection of sulfatases in mycobacterial lysates. Probe 59 as a substrate was evaluated in lysates obtained from 10 different mycobacterial species: Mtb (H37Rv, Erdman, and CDC1551), M. bovis (bacillus BCG), M. kansasii, M. avium, M. intracellulare, M. africanum, Msm, Mmn, M. nonchromogenicum, and M. septicum. The analysis revealed all these strains to possess characteristic sulfatase fingerprints, which can be used as tool to differentiate them. Importantly, 58 was unable to label human sulfatase, thus presenting itself as a powerful tool for selective analysis of sulfatase activities in clinical samples containing a mixture of human and mycobacterial cells.(182) Despite being a good probe, the hydrolysis product of 58, DDAO, emits in the extreme end of the visible spectrum (λemit = 660 nm), making its integration in low-cost devices difficult. Hence, there was a need to expand the set of sulfatase-activated fluorogenic probes, which was achieved by Smith et al. by developing 3-O-methylfluorescein-sulfate (MFS, 60) and resorufin sulfate (RS, 61), both of which give blue-shifted hydrolysis products as compared to DDAO (Figure 13).(183) The probes 60 and 61 were validated as substrates for sulfatase and were able to label most of the mycobacterium species, barring a few. None of the studied probes were hydrolyzed by mammalian lysates, demonstrating their selectivity against mycobacterial sulfatase similar to 58.(183) Among all these probes, 61 was found to be particularly sensitive, with a low detection limit, and also the most optimal mycobacterial sulfatase substrate, especially for Mtb.
    Collectivity, various probes targeting specific cell envelope components of Mtb have been developed (Figure 14) with varied application potential ranging from diagnosis and drug screening to elucidation of Mtb biology specific to host pathogen interactions. The protein-based chemical probes and their applications discussed herein are summarized in Table 2.
    Table 2. List of Protein-Based Chemical Probes and Their Applications
    probeprobe targetapplications
    tetradecanoyl-AMS-TAMARA(151)(38)FadDs enzymesfluorescence polarization (assay of FadDs inhibitors)
    Sal-AMS ABP(153)(40)adenylate enzyme MbtAABPs for adenylating enzymes in Mtb and other pathogenic Mycobacteria
    benzoxadiazoles(154)(42)transpeptidasefluorogenic assay to identify transpeptidase inhibitors in Mtb
    UDP-ABP(158)(44)UGMfluorescence polarization high-throughput assay for screening of ligands binding to UGM
    ATP-ABP(163)(45)ATP-binding proteinsidentification of novel ATP-binding proteins in Mtb
    BTZ-TAMARA(170)(48)DprE1anti-mycobacterial activity, DprE1 localization studies
    JN108(171)(49)DprE1detection of live Mtb and in cell-free extracts, anti-mycobacterial activity
    CNIR5(177)(50)β-lactamasedetection of live Mtb, real-time imaging of pulmonary infection
    CDC-OME(178)(51)β-lactamasedetection of live Mtb
    CDG-OME(178)(52)β-lactamasedetection of live Mtb in clinical specimens
    CDG-3(179)(53)β-lactamasedetection of Mtb in clinical specimens
    CDG-TRe(180)(53a)β-lactamase and Ag85detection of live BCG cells phagocytosed inside macrophages
    CDG-DNB3(181)(58)DprE1 and β-lactamasedetection of live Mtb, chip-assisted diagnosis of TB
    DDAO-sulfate, (59) MFS, (60), RS (61)(182,183)sulfataselabeling Mtb cell extracts, monitoring sulfatase activity

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The mycobacterial cell envelope and associated protein machinery present big challenges as well as opportunities for drug discovery programs and for development of chemical probes. In this Perspective, we highlight chemical probes based on mycobacterial sugars, lipids, amino acids, and proteins for selective labeling of Mtb, leveraging their cell envelope components, including mycomembrane lipids, PG, and enzymes. These probes have permitted identification and characterization of novel classes of proteins, monitoring the biosynthesis of various cell wall components, cell wall modulation by drugs, and finally clinical diagnosis of tuberculosis in a rapid and selective fashion. Of particular interest are the probes that have emanated from numerous medicinal chemistry programs in the area of TB. These are facilitating a significant part of chemical biology efforts, which are opening new avenues in virulent mechanism studies, diagnosis, and treatment. Prospectively, this review also urges the medicinal chemistry community to expand the objective of their invaluable work to include potential chemical biology implications.
    In this work, we also elaborate on the understudied potential application of Mtb lipid-based chemical tools for inventorying pathogen interactions at the host membrane interface. These probes have substantiated host membrane insertion and subsequent modulation of host membrane structure and function as a well-accepted mode of action of Mtb virulent lipids. In the future, suitably designed synthetic lipid probes can inform novel therapeutic lipid-centric strategies in TB as an alternative to protein-based approaches that are now leveling off. In addition, lipid-inspired chemoproteomic probes in the future can enrich our understanding of the Mtb lipid-regulated host proteome and pathways involved in tubercular infections, a field still in its infancy due to the lack of suitable chemical tools.
